```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_42725532e0636ed552fcb4ceb3cba138'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load data
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")
# Check it out
head(elections)
```

## Exercise 1

We need dataset, the two variables show up in the plot, and the ggplot functions. geom_point might give this plot.

## Exercise 2


::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_79293435d5c24cd5691bc751c5660406'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Set up the plotting frame
# How does this differ than the frame for our histogram of repub_pct_20 alone? 
# It has two axis with numbers.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Add a layer of points for each county
# The points show up is the frame.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Change the shape of the points
# The shape of the points become stars
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point(shape = 3)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-3.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# YOU TRY: Modify the code to make the points "orange"
# NOTE: Try to anticipate if "color" or "fill" will be useful here. Then try both.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point(color = "orange")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-4.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Add a layer that represents each county by the state it's in
# The points become the names of the states, it isn't very tidy.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = state_abbr))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-5.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Exercise 3
### It is a strong positive relation, there are some Taxes points have higher repub_pct_20.

## Exercise 4

::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_05de0a402b5a7c08ad7425c31fa33583'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### a

::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_0e6869324c7d0b1245ba1426919eb85e'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### b

::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_4fdf383be64ca64303d9366c80be8dd3'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Exercise 5


::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_6b2286378caf7c6b31b649ce50a9dbf4'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_rent
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = median_rent)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_age
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = median_age)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::

These two scatterplots don't show strong relation, and the points don't display linearly. repub_pct_20 vs median_age has a weak positive association, and repub_pct_20 vs median_rent has a negative association that is stranger than repub_pct_20 vs median_age. 


## Exercise 6


::: {.cell hash='activity-04_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_80dbbabde0b8d18ed105bf9ec02a3c03'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

It is a categorical variable, the points only shows on exactly three places on x-axis.
